title: Ding
text:
The food cauldron, known as a ding, was the most prominent ritual vessel among all other types during Chinaâ€™s Bronze Age. It was used to cook, hold, and season meat during ceremonies devoted to ancestral spirits. The vertical handles allowed the vessel to be lowered and removed from an open fire. As part of the funerary practices, such bronze dings were buried with the deceased. The number of dings constituting a set depended on the status of the tomb occupant. Rulers were supposed to be buried with 9 dings. 
 
With its spherical lidded body, three small legs, and the usual prominent handles, this ding is of a simple and elegant type that was produced during the late Warring States period (475-221 BCE) and the succeeding Qin dynasty (221-206 BCE). It contrasts sharply with the more highly decorated and architectonic ding vessels made previously.
description: round body on tall tripod legs with flat feet; pair of U-shaped handles; domed cover with four decorative scrolls; copper-colored, red and green mottled patina
